functions.name: find_and_replace_emails
functions.description: Uses a regex pattern that matches typical email addresses. The pattern accounts for alphanumeric characters, periods, hyphens, underscores, and plus signs in the local part, and domain names with subdomains and top‑level domains. It then substitutes every match with '[REDACTED]'. Edge cases such as email addresses with quoted local parts, IP literal addresses in the domain part, and internationalized domain names are ignored to keep the regex manageable.

functions.name: find_and_replace_ipv4
functions.description: Uses a regex pattern that matches IPv4 addresses where each octet is between 0 and 255. The pattern ensures that numbers like 999 or 256 are not matched. It replaces any matched IP with '[REDACTED]'. Edge cases such as IP addresses embedded in URLs or surrounded by brackets are handled by using word boundaries.

functions.name: find_and_replace_phones
functions.description: Matches common North‑American phone number formats, including optional country code '+1', area code in parentheses or not, separators such as dashes, dots, or spaces, and optional extension indicators (x, ext, extension). It replaces every match with '[REDACTED]'. The regex is case‑insensitive and allows for 10 or 11 digit sequences. It does not attempt to validate phone number length beyond basic structure to avoid excessive complexity.

functions.name: scrub_pii
functions.description: Sequentially calls find_and_replace_emails, find_and_replace_ipv4, and find_and_replace_phones on the input text. Each step receives the output of the previous step, ensuring that overlapping patterns are all redacted. The function returns the fully sanitized string.

main_logic_description: The main block imports the scrub_pii function, reads input text, and prints the redacted result. It demonstrates usage by calling scrub_pii on a sample string.
